peopleAlsoAsk.question: How can you tell if a crock is an antique?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: Antique crocks have a distinctive appearance. Each stoneware crock displays a shiny-looking surface that results from the salt glazing process. Under the glassy finish, the crock features hand-drawn or stenciled letters and numbers. Hand-painted embellishments include flowers, animals, and specific motifs or patterns.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: Value of Antique Crocks (Full Stoneware Price Guide)

peopleAlsoAsk.question: How do I know if my stoneware is valuable?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: Signs That a Stoneware Jug Is Valuable Above all, an antique stoneware jug is valuable if it was hand-painted, made in the 1700s or 1800s, and has a maker's mark. Here's how to tell if your jug is hand painted and salt-glazed: It has a shiny, glass-like surface with sparse, tiny bumps (from the salt).
peopleAlsoAsk.title: How To Tell the Value of Antique Stoneware - Woman's World

peopleAlsoAsk.question: What were 15 gallon crocks used for?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: Stoneware crocks have many uses from the traditional use of preserving vegetables like cucumbers for pickles and cabbage for sauerkraut to more decorative uses like containers for potpourri, candy, magazines, kitchen utensils, cookbooks, pens and pencils, or candles.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: Ohio Stoneware Crocks | AllAmericanCanner.com

peopleAlsoAsk.question: What makes a crock valuable?
peopleAlsoAsk.snippet: Simple and utilitarian antique stoneware, such as jugs, crocks, churns, bowls, and pitchers, get their value today from how uniquely they were manufactured. Many potters used a salt-glazing process to create a glass-like finish on jugs, crocks, and the like when firing them.
peopleAlsoAsk.title: Identifying and Valuing Antique Stoneware Jugs and Crocks
